sentences.sentence: Diversity of opinion When minorities in Australia take sides in foreign conflicts, it's not out of a refusal to integrate.
It is quite the opposite.The second casualty of war, after truth, is the slow, incessant pressure on citizen dissent.

This is not only seen among Israelis and Palestinians on the front line, but also felt here in Australia and in other liberal democracies that have been dragged into the heated debate.The sharp escalation in rhetoric and protests by supporters of both sides in the current Middle East crisis is having a chilling effect on how we debate thorny issues among ourselves.

The ABC is under pressure over its coverage, with critics slamming the suggestion there is any equivalence between the tactics of Hamas and the Israeli security forces.Given Australia is a mass-migration society, this is hardly surprising.
A generous spread of people from across the world have settled here in recent decades.

They have been keen to build a new future nourished by democratic values and expression but, naturally, many are partially invested in ties of kith and kinship - following, to remind ourselves, a two-century model created by the Anglo-Celts.Calls for greater even-handedness (from frontbenchers such as Ed Husic, Tony Burke and Anne Aly) are aimed at ensuring the nation's foreign policy does not end up being tone-deaf to anger on both sides.

The essence of their intervention is that Australia can ill-afford to take sides, given its complex and interwoven pedigree.That is unless you believe that Hamas' assault on slumbering Israeli civilians - echoing al-Qaeda's 2001 attacks on the US - amounts to a civilisational threat to the very fabric of Western society.
That belief gives Hamas too much credit and respect.

The reality is, the events of October 7 were deliberately designed to force Israel into overreaction and overreach, much as the George W. Bush-led Western alliance responded 22 years ago.Avoiding an Israeli 9/11 error: that was President Joe Biden's counsel to the stunned Israeli leadership, and it carries weight because it came from a veteran US politician who voted for wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and later regretted taking the bait.Settled communities in Australia that want to speak in solidarity with Palestinians are not refusing to integrate, unless shedding their feelings and attachments is to be set as a precondition of belonging.
Suggesting Australia has a fifth column problem (as Ramesh Thakur, a former UN assistant secretary-general, did on these pages) is itself an attack on Australian democracy.

What is at stake is Australians' right to dissent.Those who have settled here over 200 years have not done so unconditionally, without the right to argue and protest for different public policy, whether in foreign affairs or domestically.
Policies change, often because of voter dissatisfaction, so long as it is voiced within the law.

This is a feature of the democratic process we should cherish and encourage if we are to develop as a forward-thinking nation.The very essence of liberal integration is to sign up to a political system that includes the right, but not the requirement, to exercise dissent.
Going off to join Islamic State on the battlefield is outside the law.

Calling for understanding of the Palestinians' plight in very much within the law, just as public sympathy for Israeli civilian losses is as well.Inflammatory hatred, such as the appalling chants to "gas the Jews" in Sydney, is not the legitimate expression of dissent.
However awkward it is to admit it, there are a few among those sympathetic to the Palestinians who are simply antisemitic.
Crises often uncover such bedfellows.This creates an awkwardness for the ALP, in particular, which has a lot of settled Muslim-Australians among its support base in many large capital cities.

In the UK, the directly elected Labour mayors of London and Manchester, along with Labour's leader in Scotland, have broken ranks with the national Labour leader's perceived backing for Israel's Gaza campaign.The better and more effective approach lies in challenging (and removing the scope for) local political leaders who want to run municipal foreign policies.

This is no more coherent when dealing with relations with China as it is in addressing how Australia as a sovereign nation interacts with Israel or the Palestinian territories.Many countries such as Australia today comprise complex diaspora and minorities who occasionally will seek to influence national policy decisions.

That is a healthy sign because the eventual outcome is not predetermined by a hidden hand inferring what the national interest is.Thirty years ago, the Congressional Black Caucus claimed credit for a U-turn in the Clinton White House's policy towards Haiti.

It succeeded because it effected singular change in national policy, and it did not pit American against American.In the future, Australians of different ancestries might be split and become dangerously animated on a hypothetical conflict with China or an Indian-Pakistani flashpoint boiling over.
The role of the federal government is to forge credible foreign policy that is bound to have dissenters.

It is naive to suggest otherwise.The common denominator in the Middle East today is the incapacity of warring sides to imagine they might one day show respect for one another.Australians' freedom to express their dissent over how they - and we - might get there is a valuable asset which we must defend in the darkest hour of conflict.Shamit Saggar is a professor at Curtin University and visiting professor at King's College London, and was a senior official in the Blair UK government's strategy unit.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
documents.inputText: Diversity of opinion When minorities in Australia take sides in foreign conflicts, it's not out of a refusal to integrate. It is quite the opposite.The second casualty of war, after truth, is the slow, incessant pressure on citizen dissent. This is not only seen among Israelis and Palestinians on the front line, but also felt here in Australia and in other liberal democracies that have been dragged into the heated debate.The sharp escalation in rhetoric and protests by supporters of both sides in the current Middle East crisis is having a chilling effect on how we debate thorny issues among ourselves. The ABC is under pressure over its coverage, with critics slamming the suggestion there is any equivalence between the tactics of Hamas and the Israeli security forces.Given Australia is a mass-migration society, this is hardly surprising. A generous spread of people from across the world have settled here in recent decades. They have been keen to build a new future nourished by democratic values and expression but, naturally, many are partially invested in ties of kith and kinship - following, to remind ourselves, a two-century model created by the Anglo-Celts.Calls for greater even-handedness (from frontbenchers such as Ed Husic, Tony Burke and Anne Aly) are aimed at ensuring the nation's foreign policy does not end up being tone-deaf to anger on both sides. The essence of their intervention is that Australia can ill-afford to take sides, given its complex and interwoven pedigree.That is unless you believe that Hamas' assault on slumbering Israeli civilians - echoing al-Qaeda's 2001 attacks on the US - amounts to a civilisational threat to the very fabric of Western society. That belief gives Hamas too much credit and respect. The reality is, the events of October 7 were deliberately designed to force Israel into overreaction and overreach, much as the George W. Bush-led Western alliance responded 22 years ago.Avoiding an Israeli 9/11 error: that was President Joe Biden's counsel to the stunned Israeli leadership, and it carries weight because it came from a veteran US politician who voted for wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and later regretted taking the bait.Settled communities in Australia that want to speak in solidarity with Palestinians are not refusing to integrate, unless shedding their feelings and attachments is to be set as a precondition of belonging. Suggesting Australia has a fifth column problem (as Ramesh Thakur, a former UN assistant secretary-general, did on these pages) is itself an attack on Australian democracy. What is at stake is Australians' right to dissent.Those who have settled here over 200 years have not done so unconditionally, without the right to argue and protest for different public policy, whether in foreign affairs or domestically. Policies change, often because of voter dissatisfaction, so long as it is voiced within the law. Going off to join Islamic State on the battlefield is outside the law. However awkward it is to admit it, there are a few among those sympathetic to the Palestinians who are simply antisemitic. Crises often uncover such bedfellows.This creates an awkwardness for the ALP, in particular, which has a lot of settled Muslim-Australians among its support base in many large capital cities. In the UK, the directly elected Labour mayors of London and Manchester, along with Labour's leader in Scotland, have broken ranks with the national Labour leader's perceived backing for Israel's Gaza campaign.The better and more effective approach lies in challenging (and removing the scope for) local political leaders who want to run municipal foreign policies. This is no more coherent when dealing with relations with China as it is in addressing how Australia as a sovereign nation interacts with Israel or the Palestinian territories.Many countries such as Australia today comprise complex diaspora and minorities who occasionally will seek to influence national policy decisions. That is a healthy sign because the eventual outcome is not predetermined by a hidden hand inferring what the national interest is.Thirty years ago, the Congressional Black Caucus claimed credit for a U-turn in the Clinton White House's policy towards Haiti. It succeeded because it effected singular change in national policy, and it did not pit American against American.In the future, Australians of different ancestries might be split and become dangerously animated on a hypothetical conflict with China or an Indian-Pakistani flashpoint boiling over.
